metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: Leaf area index of Sidaoqiao superstation, 2023
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the LAI measurements from the Sidaoqiao in the downstream of the Heihe integrated observatory network from August 8 to October 31 in 2023. The site was located in Ejina Banner in Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. The elevation is 870 m. There are 1 observation samples, around Sidaoqiao superstation (101.1374E, 42.0012N), which is about 30m×30m in size. Five sub-canopy nodes and one above-canopy node are arranged in each sample. 
The data is obtained from LAINet measurements; the four-steps are performed to obtain LAI: the raw data is light quantum (level 0); the daily LAI can be obtained using the software LAInet (level 1); further the invalid and null values are screened and using the 7 days moving averaged method to obtain the processed LAI (level 2); for the multi LAINet nodes observation, the averaged LAI of the nodes area is the final LAI (level 3).
The released data are the post processed LAI products and its standard deviation and stored using *.xls format.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) and Liu et al. (2023).

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid regions?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to monitor leaf area index in arid regions is the use of a wireless sensor network known as LAINet. This method involves setting up multiple nodes under and above the canopy to automatically collect hourly light data at each node, which is then processed to calculate daily leaf area index values.

Definition.Question: What is the role of a wireless sensor network in collecting leaf area index data?
Definition.Answer: A wireless sensor network, such as the LAINet, is used to automatically gather light data from various nodes positioned above and below the canopy. This data is then processed to calculate the leaf area index, allowing for continuous and detailed monitoring of vegetation characteristics.

Definition.Question: How is data quality maintained in datasets that involve energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations?
Definition.Answer: Data quality is maintained through a structured process of data collection, processing, quality control, and archiving. Observational datasets are collected using instruments like the eddy covariance system and scintillometer, and are supplemented by auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters, ensuring comprehensive and accurate datasets.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with monitoring inland river basins in arid and semiarid regions?
Definition.Answer: Monitoring inland river basins in arid and semiarid regions involves addressing ecological crises such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, degradation of natural vegetation, intensification of land desertification, and frequent dust storms, which are particularly prevalent in areas like the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques for leaf area index using LAINet compare to those used for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection for leaf area index using LAINet involves wireless sensor networks that automatically gather light data at regular intervals, which is then processed to calculate LAI. In contrast, data collection for energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange involves using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers for flux data and automatic weather stations for hydrometeorological parameters, with a focus on long-term, continuous data acquisition.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the challenges faced in data collection for inland river basins in arid regions compared to oasis–desert ecosystems?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection in inland river basins faces challenges like ecological degradation, river and lake drying, and land desertification, often exacerbated by climate change. Oasis–desert ecosystems, while also affected by arid conditions, require balancing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange to maintain ecological stability and socio-economic development, with a strong focus on sustainable oasis development.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of LAINet wireless sensor networks influence the accuracy and reliability of data collected on leaf area index in arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: LAINet wireless sensor networks provide automated, high-frequency light data collection from multiple nodes, enabling detailed, time-sensitive insights into leaf area index variations. By processing this data to mitigate weather-induced variability and filling in missing values, the method enhances data reliability and allows for accurate averaging across observational sub-regions.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges might arise in maintaining long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert ecosystems, and how can these be addressed through methodological improvements?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in maintaining long-term datasets include environmental degradation, such as drying rivers and vegetation loss, and extreme weather events. Methodological improvements could involve the deployment of robust automatic weather stations and data quality control measures to ensure consistent data acquisition and archiving.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for processing raw observational data from wireless sensor networks in specific environmental monitoring projects?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The processing of raw observational data from wireless sensor networks, such as the LAINet, is necessary to calculate daily leaf area index values and eliminate the impact of weather fluctuations by applying a 7-day moving average. This processing helps in identifying and filling invalid values to derive meaningful insights into the environmental conditions at the observation site.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it essential to maintain long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are essential in oasis–desert ecosystems because they provide a quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which is crucial for recognizing oasis–desert interactions. This knowledge supports ecological security, sustainable development, and helps achieve goals like carbon peaking and carbon neutrality.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What are the underlying causes leading to the degradation of ecological environments in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The degradation of ecological environments in inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas is caused by factors such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms. These issues are particularly prevalent in many basins along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin and the Aral Sea basin.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for leaf area index data collection in terms of data accuracy and temporal resolution?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using wireless sensor networks such as LAINet allows for automatic data collection at a high temporal resolution, with observations being recorded hourly. This can enhance data accuracy by providing continuous monitoring and reducing manual errors. However, challenges may arise in terms of data processing, such as identifying and filling invalid values and accounting for weather variations with methods like a 7-day sliding average.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations in arid regions influence the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The establishment of multiple land surface flux and meteorological stations can improve the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange processes by providing long-term, multi-location datasets. These datasets allow for the analysis of spatial and temporal variations in these exchanges, which is crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and maintaining ecological stability in arid regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from the integration of auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters into ecosystem studies in oasis-desert systems?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters into ecosystem studies can provide a comprehensive view of the factors influencing energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges. This data integration can enhance the accuracy of ecosystem models, support sustainable development strategies, and offer insights into maintaining the ecological balance in oasis-desert systems.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives for collecting leaf area index data using wireless sensor networks in arid and semiarid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives for collecting leaf area index data using wireless sensor networks in arid and semiarid regions include understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems to achieve goals related to carbon peaking and carbon neutrality, as well as supporting ecological security and sustainable development in these areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Long-term observational datasets of energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems are important to quantitatively understand oasis–desert interactions, protect ecological stability, and support the socioeconomic development of oases, especially in the context of achieving sustainable oasis development.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are long-term energy, water vapor, and carbon flux datasets collected and processed in oasis–desert systems, and what instruments are typically used?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term datasets on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes are collected using eddy covariance systems and scintillometers, which provide half-hourly turbulent flux data. Additionally, automated weather stations recording various hydrometeorological parameters such as radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles, among others, help supplement the dataset. Data processing includes collection, quality control, and archiving for future sharing.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to differentiate and analyze oasis and desert interactions within inland river basins in arid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Methodologies involve using observational datasets from both artificial and natural oasis–desert systems, which include energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane flux data, along with auxiliary data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are collected using instruments like eddy covariance systems and automatic weather stations, and are vital for understanding oasis–desert interactions and supporting ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Enablement.Question: What technological methods enable the accurate collection of leaf area index data in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The collection of leaf area index data in arid regions is enabled by the use of a wireless sensor network known as LAINet, which automatically gathers light data from multiple nodes daily and hourly. The data is then processed using specialized software to calculate daily LAI, identify and fill invalid values, and average them over a period to mitigate weather impact.

Enablement.Question: How does the integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers enhance the measurement of energy and carbon fluxes in oasis–desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: The integration of eddy covariance systems and scintillometers allows for the acquisition of half-hourly turbulent flux data, which is crucial for understanding the energy and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems. This approach provides high-resolution temporal data, enabling more precise analysis of these fluxes over time.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in maintaining consistent data collection for leaf area index in arid and semiarid regions?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face environmental degradation challenges like drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, intensified desertification, and frequent dust storms, which could affect consistent data collection efforts.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected challenges in using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in desert-oasis systems?
Expectation.Answer: Collecting data in desert-oasis systems using wireless sensor networks might be challenging due to the need for long-term observations to understand energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, as well as maintaining ecological stability amidst harsh environmental conditions.

Expectation.Question: Why is there a necessity for long-term observations when studying energy and carbon exchanges in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: Long-term observations are critical for understanding the interactions between oasis and desert systems, which are important for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, and for supporting the ecological security and sustainable development of oases.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using wireless sensor networks like LAINet for collecting leaf area index data in arid regions?
Judgmental.Answer: Wireless sensor networks like LAINet are effective for collecting leaf area index data as they provide automated, continuous, and detailed observations, which are crucial for capturing the dynamics in arid regions where environmental conditions can rapidly change. However, their deployment might face challenges related to harsh environmental conditions that could affect sensor performance and data transmission.

Assertion.Answer: Data collection in oasis–desert ecosystems involves long-term observational datasets that include energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes, and auxiliary data like hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. These datasets are collected using systems such as eddy covariance and automatic weather stations, which provide detailed insights into the unique characteristics of oasis and desert ecosystems.

Assertion.Answer: Challenges in maintaining data quality in arid and semiarid regions include dealing with ecological environment degradation like drying rivers and lakes, vegetation degradation, land desertification, and dust storms. These environmental factors can impact data collection and require rigorous data processing and quality control procedures to ensure consistency and accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used for gathering leaf area index (LAI) observations in arid and semi-arid regions, focusing on the techniques and instruments involved.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for gathering leaf area index (LAI) observations in arid and semi-arid regions involve the use of a wireless sensor network known as LAINet. This system automatically gathers light data every hour from both canopy and sub-canopy nodes. Data processing involves computing daily LAI values, identifying and filling invalid values, and applying a 7-day moving average to mitigate weather-related fluctuations. The final processed dataset includes LAI averages and standard deviations for multiple plots.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify and discuss the challenges associated with maintaining ecological stability and conducting long-term observations in oasis–desert ecosystems.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in maintaining ecological stability in oasis–desert ecosystems include ecological environment degradation such as drying up of water bodies, degradation of natural vegetation, intensifying desertification, and frequent dust storms. Inland river basins, particularly those westward along the Silk Road, face pronounced environmental crises. Long-term observations are crucial to understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges in these areas to support ecological security and sustainable development.

Request/Directive.Question: Please investigate potential datasets available for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems, including the types of data collected and their availability.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for studying energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert systems include those from the middle and lower reaches of the HRB. Since 2012, 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established, collecting data on energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, along with hydrometeorological data and vegetation and soil parameters. These datasets are freely available through the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.
